instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in boot loop with kernel panic
threads.message:
This 2015 Pro chimes, begins booting,  kernel panics, tries to restart.
I've already replaced the EFI (<CHIP>U6100</CHIP>) with a clean ME region. Also replaced <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> and checked the EFI termination resistors.

What's keeping this board from loading the BIOS?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in boot loop with kernel panic
threads.message:
If chimes, PCH accesses BIOS and board boots.

Tried USB macOS?
You can also test with Windows Live, or Linux.

Still panics in safe mode?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in boot loop with kernel panic
threads.message: Still panics in safe mode and with external USB drive using macOS. The only thing that does work is running ubuntu from USB.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in boot loop with kernel panic
threads.message:
I just found an old SSD with High Sierra on it, and the machine boots fine with this OS. However, it randomly kernel panics later during use (report attached).

Running Apple Diagnostics stalls in the early stages of testing.

Failing CPU or RAM on this machine?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in boot loop with kernel panic
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in boot loop with kernel panic
threads.message: I also noticed that there is a discrepancy between the amount of RAM printed on the logic board (8GB) and that reported by System Information (16GB). No idea how that is possible... ? Shouldn't a PRAM reset correct this?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck in boot loop with kernel panic
threads.message:
Check the capacity of your RAM chips and guess te real amount.
You may find it in Gb, not GB, then should divide by 8; 1GB=8Gb.
See if you have 2GB, or 4GB chips.
